Tiny Refinements Elicit Resilience: Toward Efficient Prefix-Model Against LLM Red-Teaming

Jiaxu Liu 1â‹† , Xiangyu Yin 1â‹† , Sihao Wu 1
Jianhong Wang 2 , Meng Fang 1 , Xinping Yi 3 , Xiaowei Huang 1
1 University of Liverpool, 2 University of Manchester, 3 Southeast University
{firstname.lastname} @liverpool.ac.uk, jianhong.wang@manchester.ac.uk, xyi@seu.edu.cn
Abstract

With the proliferation of red-teaming strategies for Large Language Models (LLMs), the deficiency in the literature about improving the safety and robustness of LLM defense strategies is becoming increasingly pronounced. This paper introduces the LLM-based sentinel model as a plug-and-play prefix module designed to reconstruct the input prompt with just a few ( < 30 absent 30 <30 ) additional tokens, effectively reducing toxicity in responses from target LLMs. The sentinel model naturally overcomes the parameter inefficiency and limited model accessibility for fine-tuning large target models. We employ an interleaved training regimen using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) to optimize both red team and sentinel models dynamically, incorporating a value head-sharing mechanism inspired by the multi-agent centralized critic to manage the complex interplay between agents. Our extensive experiments across text-to-text and text-to-image demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in mitigating toxic outputs, even when dealing with larger models like Llama-2 , GPT-3.5 and Stable-Diffusion , highlighting the potential of our framework in enhancing safety and robustness in various applications.

WARNING: This paper contains AI-generated contents that are offensive in nature.

1 Introduction

While the advancement of Large Language Models (LLMs) ( OpenAI, 2023a, ; OpenAI, 2023b, ; Taori etÂ al.,, 2023 ) has been instrumental in catalyzing a paradigm shift in General Artificial Intelligence, their reliability and trustworthiness are not absolute. For example, these models are prone to exhibiting undesirable behaviors like hallucination (Li etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Rawte etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Zhang etÂ al.,, 2023 ) , personal information leakage ( e.g., social security numbers) (Carlini etÂ al.,, 2019 ; Kim etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Plant etÂ al.,, 2022 ) and may generate misinformation, bias, hatefulness, or toxic content (Burns etÂ al.,, 2022 ; Kuhn etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Lin etÂ al., 2022a, ; Lin etÂ al., 2022b, ; Menick etÂ al.,, 2022 ; Ousidhoum etÂ al.,, 2021 ; Petroni etÂ al.,, 2021 ; Thorne etÂ al.,, 2018 ) . Such vulnerabilities underscore the critical need for identifying flaws and uncovering undesirable outcomes when using LLMs. Based on this, the red-teaming strategies, especially the model-based red teaming (Casper etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ; Mehrabi etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Perez etÂ al.,, 2022 ) , which exploits third-party models to craft prompts that would trigger the targeting model and generate toxic texts, has attracted substantial attention in recent years. For instance, (Perez etÂ al.,, 2022 ) employed a pre-trained classifier as the reward mechanism to fine-tune a red-teaming model. This aims at crafting inputs that would optimize the reward score, reflecting the effectiveness of the model in evoking specific responses from a target system.

However, with the proliferation of red-teaming strategies for LLMs, there is a growing need for more efficient and flexible defense methods that can improve the safety and robustness of LLMs against various red-teaming approaches. Current methods face two key limitations: (I) Parameter Efficiency : Techniques like fine-tuning LLMs on detoxified corpora ( Gehman etÂ al., 2020a, ) or using an infected model for self-detoxification (Xu etÂ al.,, 2022 ) require retraining the entire victim LLM, which becomes prohibitively expensive for large models like Llama-2-70B (Touvron etÂ al.,, 2023 ) . Recent work on LLM guardrails (Dong etÂ al.,, 2024 ; Inan etÂ al.,, 2023 ) also relies on curating large datasets for fine-tuning, limiting their scalability. (II) Model Accessibility : Dataset filtration (Ngo etÂ al.,, 2021 ) during LLM pre-training has been proposed as a more scalable defense. However, this approach cannot be applied to API-based models like GPT-3.5/4 and Claude 2 , as their training data/weight is not accessible. The need to access an LLMâ€™s weights or training data restricts the applicability of existing defense methods. This underscores a notable gap in addressing issues related to security, privacy, and commercial usage.

To address the identified limitations, we propose the LLM-based sentinel: a lightweight, plug-and-play approach that can be prepended to any LLM to elicit safer responses without fine-tuning the base model itself. Specifically, the high-lvel idea is illustrated in Fig. 1 : the red-teaming model generates tokens based on the input prompt, sampled from a corpus, producing a potentially toxic prompt that may elicit harmful responses from the target model. The sentinel model observes the full event and generate additional tokens to create a refined prompt, guiding the target model to produce a safe, non-toxic response. In the training phase, the sentinel is fine-tuned adversarially against a red-teaming LLM using proximal policy optimization (PPO) to identify and nullify evolving attack patterns. This allows it to adapt more efficiently than static defense methods. Further, we conceptualize the training dynamics as a two-agent Stackelberg game (Brero etÂ al.,, 2022 ; Li and Sethi,, 2017 ) . With the red-teaming model as an independent leader and the sentinel model as a follower , we develop the value-head-sharing mechanism inspired by MAPPO to address partial agent dependency. We validate our defense method through experiments across text-to-text and text-to-image tasks with various model configurations.

In summary, our key contributions are: (1) The sentinel defense model, which intercepts and modifies potentially toxic prompts using a small number of strategically chosen prefix tokens, without affecting the base LLMâ€™s parameters or requiring access to its training data. (2) An adversarial training framework in which the sentinel is optimized alongside a red-teaming LLM using PPO. We model their interaction as a two-player Stackelberg game and exploit the value head sharing mechanism inspired by multi-agent PPO to address partial observability. (3) An extensive empirical evaluation demonstrating the sentinelâ€™s effectiveness at mitigating toxic outputs across text-to-text and text-to-image tasks for LLMs of various sizes, without sacrificing generation quality.

2 Methodology

The methodology for training these two LLM-like agents is further detailed in Appendix A (Fig. 9 ), where we describe the principal functions that facilitate the two-LLM-agent training, respectively, the Make Experience (target interaction), Process Element (RL element computation), and PPO Learn (model update).

Remark. A commonly posed concern is: will optimizing Eq.Â ( 3 ) implicate the update of both Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} and Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} , since Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} requires the outputs from Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} ? The answer is negative, we justify in two-fold: (i) The text re-tokenization between adjacent LLMs interrupts the gradient flow, as the tokenizer is not differentiable, making it impossible to accumulate gradients from Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} to Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} ; (ii) Our framework requires that the two models be trained on their respective rewards. Since PPO train individual agents with (state, action, reward) tuples, it naturally prevents the re-optimization of other agents.

2.3 Stabilizing Training via Resolving Partial Dependencies

As our setup for interactive training is a Stackelberg game, the red-teaming model generates toxic tokens with no knowledge from the sentinel, while the sentinel has full information from the red team. This suggests the red-team as a standalone module in our framework, decorated from the sentinel, making it challenging to generate harsh information specifically for the sentinel. This complication enlarges the search space of both models that potentially leads to instability of interactive training. We resolve this via modifying the value prediction modeling under multi-agent scheme.

Autoregressive Model with Shared Value Head. To predict the subsequent tokens in LLM-based agents (decoder-only transformers), the current sentence is embedded using transformer blocks, then passed through a feed-forward network with softmax to obtain token logprobs. A greedy/sampling strategy selects the next token based on the probability vector. For token value prediction, the same embedding is input to a separate value function network, outputting a scalar value for each token. To resolve such partial agent dependency, in our work, we also develop the value head-sharing mechanism for LLM-based agents inspired by MAPPO to enhance the training. The centralized/shared value head incorporates both self-observation and information other agents provide to support critical learning.

Starting from the formulation of independent setting Eq.Â ( 4 ), where f Î¸ subscript ğ‘“ ğœƒ f_{\theta} and g Ï• subscript ğ‘” italic-Ï• g_{\phi} are decoders and encoder networks with parameters Î¸ ğœƒ \theta and Ï• italic-Ï• \phi , x ğ‘¥ x is the embedding for each language model, for two LLM-agents, the input embeddings are different. The centralized Eq.Â ( 4 ) can be reformulated as Eq.Â ( 5 ) by letting Î¸ s = Î¸ r subscript ğœƒ ğ‘  subscript ğœƒ ğ‘Ÿ \theta_{s}=\theta_{r} and Ï• s = Ï• r subscript italic-Ï• ğ‘  subscript italic-Ï• ğ‘Ÿ \phi_{s}=\phi_{r} . Empirically, as shown in (Brero etÂ al.,, 2022 ) , agents with centralized value functions in the Stackelberg game generally outperform those with individual value functions. Finally, we introduce the partially shared mode in Eq.Â ( 6 ) where sg â¡ ( â‹… ) sg â‹… \operatorname{sg}(\cdot) denotes stop gradient. Eq.Â ( 6 ) introduce auxiliary encoder for each agent, which has the same architecture to the primary encoder of opponent agents. During the forward pass, only primary encoders in both agents are trained using gradient, whereas the auxiliary encoder of each agent update the weight merging the weights of primary encoders from other agents. Finally, the representations of each encoder are concatenated and decoded, respectively, to obtain their values. We detail the loss in Appendix B .

Remark. The centralized mode as Eq.Â ( 5 ) may bring in potential instability when modeling competitive scenarios. This is because individual heads are forced to learn predicting drastically varied values for competitive agents. The introduced partially shared mode as in Eq.Â ( 6 ) resolve this by appending the auxiliary encoders with the shared information based on independent mode as Eq.Â ( 4 ). This helps leveraging information from all agents without limiting the stability.

3 Experiments

We investigate the sentinel modelâ€™s ability to defend against red-teaming-generated test cases across various tasks and performance metrics. In Sec. 3.3 , we compare RLHF baselines, followed by an analysis of value head sharing effects on performance in Sec. 3.4 . Using the best RL setting and value head strategy, we evaluate the sentinel modelâ€™s size-agnosticism with Llama-2-7B / GPT-3.5-Turbo as target models in Sec. 3.5 . Sec. 3.6 compares our method to direct PPO detoxification baselines, assessing the sentinel modelâ€™s toxicity score and parameter efficiency. Finally, Sec. 3.8 demonstrates our methodâ€™s applicability to text-to-image scenarios using Stable-Diffusion . For additional usefulness evaluation, we detail the evaluation with DeepEval in Sec. 3.7 .

3.1 Experiment Metrics

Quality Metric. We define the quality of red-teaming model Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} and sentinel model Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} as the toxicity reward of responses obtained from the target LLM p t subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ p_{t} . Given the outputs x âˆ¼ Ï€ r ( â‹… | z ) x\sim\pi_{r}(\cdot|z) and x â‹† âˆ¼ Ï€ s ( â‹… | z ) x^{\star}\sim\pi_{s}(\cdot|z) , the outputs are considered toxic if the toxicity reward R â€‹ ( y ) ğ‘… ğ‘¦ R(y) and R â€‹ ( y â‹† ) ğ‘… superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† R(y^{\star}) predicted by the classifier R âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] ğ‘… 0 1 R\in[0,1] is high, where y âˆ¼ p t â€‹ ( x ) similar-to ğ‘¦ subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘¥ y\sim p_{t}(x) and y â‹† âˆ¼ p t â€‹ ( x â‹† ) similar-to superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ superscript ğ‘¥ â‹† y^{\star}\sim p_{t}(x^{\star}) . We choose the hate speech classifier, RoBERTa (Vidgen etÂ al.,, 2021 ) , as in (Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ) to predict the toxicity reward of target LLM responses.

Training Metric. To provide a more concise summary of both red-teaming and defense performance, we devise an overall metric,

Essentially, R mae Î³ superscript subscript ğ‘… mae ğ›¾ R_{\mathrm{mae}}^{\gamma} is a weighted mean absolute error combining the optimization target of both the red-teaming and sentinel model. Î» ğœ† \lambda is a trade-off parameter measuring the importance between red-teaming and sentinel-defense performance. The best cases are achieved when (i) R â€‹ ( y ) â†’ 1 â†’ ğ‘… ğ‘¦ 1 R(y)\to 1 , indicating high-toxicity responses triggered by the red-teaming, and (ii) R â€‹ ( y â‹† ) â†’ 0 â†’ ğ‘… superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† 0 R(y^{\star})\to 0 , indicating successful defenses by the sentinel. Thus optimally, a good multi-LLM competitive framework as depicted in Fig. 2 expects R mae â†’ 0 â†’ subscript ğ‘… mae 0 R_{\mathrm{mae}}\to 0 .

3.2 Untrained Sentinel Fails in Defense

To better understand the impact of the sentinel, we first conduct an experiment in which only the red-teaming model is trained in our framework. In other words, only Eq.Â ( 2 ) is optimized while Eq.Â ( 3 ) is not optimized. In this experiment, we expect to see that the sentinel fails to neutralize the toxic prompt from the red-teaming model.

Setup. We illustrate the results on the text continuation task, which is vital for applications relying on the modelâ€™s ability to extend and complete provided input prompts. Specifically, we follow (Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ) and use the sampled and truncated reviews from the corpus in IMDb dataset (Maas etÂ al.,, 2011 ) . These truncated texts are regarded as z âˆ¼ ğ’Ÿ similar-to ğ‘§ ğ’Ÿ z\sim\mathcal{D} for the red team model to test if it can add a few words to z ğ‘§ z and provoke toxic responses from the target LLM (as in Fig. 1 ). We use GPT2-imdb as our target LLM p t subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ p_{t} , which is a GPT2 fine-tuned on the IMDb dataset. We initialize the red team model Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} as GPT2 , and also sentinel model Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} as GPT2 . The red-teaming process incorporates taking the prompt z ğ‘§ z and generating extended x ğ‘¥ x , which is then fed into p t subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ p_{t} to produce response y ğ‘¦ y . In the sentinel process, z ğ‘§ z undergoes a similar initial step through Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} , but then x ğ‘¥ x is further refined by Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} into x â‹† superscript ğ‘¥ â‹† x^{\star} before being inputted into p t subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ p_{t} to generate response y â‹† superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† y^{\star} . In this experiment, the PPO process for optimizing reward Eq.Â ( 3 ) is not performed, hence we hold sentinel untrained. We let the bonus coefficient Î² 2 = 0 subscript ğ›½ 2 0 \beta_{2}=0 and perform vanilla RL for simplicity.

Results. Fig. 4 demonstrates the rewards on the toxified responses y ğ‘¦ y and the purified responses y â‹† superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† y^{\star} during the optimization of PPO. As we can observe, the reward of the red team ( R â€‹ ( y ) ğ‘… ğ‘¦ R(y) , red curve) progressively increases during training, this shows the effectiveness of red-teaming on generating toxic prompts. On the other hand, with similar amplitude, the sentinel reward ( R â€‹ ( y â‹† ) ğ‘… superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† R(y^{\star}) , blue curve) also blows up monotonically, proving that untrained sentinel cannot defend red-teaming , even when red team model has zero knowledge of the sentinel when training with Eq.Â ( 2 ). Fig. 4 b plots the training metric as mentioned in Eq.Â ( 7 ) where we observe R mae Î³ superscript subscript ğ‘… mae ğ›¾ R_{\mathrm{mae}}^{\gamma} (with Î³ = 0.5 ğ›¾ 0.5 \gamma=0.5 ) cannot converge to a near zero value, indicating the sentinel fail to defend the red-teaming attack.

3.3 Sentinel Effectiveness under Various RL Settings

Setup. In this section, we enable the training of both Eq.Â ( 2 ) and ( 3 ), and explore the capabilities of the red team-sentinel interaction in both Text Continuation (TC) and Instruction Following (IF). The setup of TC is the same as in Sec. 3.2 . For IF tasks, which are vital in chatbot and AI assistant applications, unlike TC, the goal for the LLM is to respond to questions or fulfill requests in the test cases. We adapt the prompt template from (Taori etÂ al.,, 2023 ) to simulate a user-bot conversation, with a blank section for the target LLM to respond. Our target models for this task are GPT2-alpaca , a GPT2 model fine-tuned with the Alpaca dataset (Taori etÂ al.,, 2023 ) . To generate instruction-like test cases, we randomly sample combinations of instructions from the Alpaca as the context z ğ‘§ z . Then we follow a similar process in TC, where Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} provokes toxic responses and Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} attempts to refine outputs from Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} for defense. A critical difference is that x âˆ¼ Ï€ r similar-to ğ‘¥ subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ x\sim\pi_{r} in this case does not include z âˆ¼ ğ’Ÿ similar-to ğ‘§ ğ’Ÿ z\sim\mathcal{D} , therefore the target models p t subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ p_{t} cannot observe z ğ‘§ z . We pack the generated prompt x / x â‹† ğ‘¥ superscript ğ‘¥ â‹† x/x^{\star} following the template in Appendix C as target input. We evaluate the performance of both models on Vanilla RL (Eq.Â ( 2 - 3 ), Î² 2 = 0 subscript ğ›½ 2 0 \beta_{2}=0 ), RL+TDiv (as in (Casper etÂ al.,, 2023 ) ) and RL+Curiosity (Eq.Â ( 2 - 3 )) settings. Each experiments are evaluated with five random seeds per method. Detailed parameter settings can be found in Tab. 4 - 5 , Appendix D .

Results. In Fig. 5(a) - 5(b) , we first access the ability of Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} on provoking toxic responses from target p t subscript ğ‘ ğ‘¡ p_{t} . We begin by evaluating the portion of toxic responses each method elicits, which reflects the efficacy of a red-teaming strategy. In Fig. 5(a) .i for TC and Fig. 5(b) .i for IF, the results suggest that the RL+Curiosity , compared to the other two approaches, leads to the highest toxicity reward for response y ğ‘¦ y . This indicates that incorporating curiosity-driven exploration improves the effectiveness of the red-teaming process and increases the difficulty of defense. On the other hand, we demonstrate the performance of Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} , where the sentinel is leveraged to counteract the toxicity increment as in Fig. 5(a) .i & Fig. 5(b) .i. In Fig. 5(a) .ii and Fig. 5(b) .ii, we evaluate the reward of toxic responses y â‹† superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† y^{\star} . Compared to y ğ‘¦ y induced by Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} , y â‹† superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† y^{\star} is filtered by Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} . Therefore, as expected, the R â€‹ ( y â‹† ) ğ‘… superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† R(y^{\star}) converges to near-zero values with all RL approaches. For all groups, we observe clear fluctuations on R â€‹ ( y â‹† ) ğ‘… superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† R(y^{\star}) near the epochs where R â€‹ ( y ) ğ‘… ğ‘¦ R(y) start to drastically increase, this suggests Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} observed the toxicity injection from Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} and attempted to defend. Fig. 5(a) .iii & Fig. 5(b) .iii suggest the sentinel works under all RL settings compared to training metric of untrained sentinel in Fig. 4 b. Given the good result of RL+Curiosity group, we employ this for rest of our evaluations.

3.4 Sentinel Effectiveness under Various Value Heads Strategies

Setup. We employ the same setups for TC and IF as detailed in Sec. 3.2 and Sec. 3.3 . As empirically shown in Sec. 3.3 , RL+Curiosity works the best in terms of training metric R mae subscript ğ‘… mae R_{\mathrm{mae}} , thus we set the curiosity approach as a baseline for evaluating three different value head strategies. Specifically, we benchmark the performance of red team-sentinel framework on Independent (Eq.Â ( 4 )), Centralized (Eq.Â ( 5 )), and Partially Shared (Eq.Â ( 6 )) settings, evaluating each method on 5 5 5 random seeds. Parameter configurations are in Tab. 4 - 5 , Appendix D .

Results. In Fig. 6(a) - 6(b) , we access the performance of three value head strategies under RL+Curiosity. For the TC task, we observe slightly higher rewards in Fig. 6(a) .i exhibited by Partially Shared compared to the other two approaches. Meanwhile, Fig. 6(a) shows both agents under Partially Shared exhibit lower variance on high epoch compared to the other two approaches, suggesting that value functions with partial consensus stabilize training in PPO. For the more complex IF task, we observe a significantly better sentinel model reward in Fig. 6(b) .ii with Partially Shared , even with the same amount of toxicity trigger as in Fig. 6(b) .i. Given the overall metric in Fig. 6(b) .iii also proves the prominence of partial value function sharing, it suggests that the shared modules learn more effectively from the varied experiences encountered by different agents in PPO, evident from the reduced variance and the improved performance on reward, especially in more challenging tasks.

3.5 Larger Model as Target Model

Since the scale of GPT2 is relatively small, we also demonstrate the efficacy of our approach against larger models like Llama-2-7B-Chat and GPT-3.5-Turbo ( âˆ¼ similar-to \sim 175B), without actually fine-tuning the large model. We employ the vaniila Curiosity and Curiosity + Partially Shared (tagged with â€  â€  {\dagger} ) setting. Similarly to the description in Sec. 3.3 , we employ the Alpaca corpus to trigger the red-teaming prompt. We detail the parameter configurations in Tab. 6 - 7 , Appendix D .

Remarkably, as demonstrated in Fig. 7 .i/Fig. 7 .i, the experiment exhibited a consistent increase in R â€‹ ( y ) ğ‘… ğ‘¦ R(y) and a decrease in R â€‹ ( y â‹† ) ğ‘… superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† R(y^{\star}) after 1000 âˆ¼ 1500 similar-to 1000 1500 1000\sim 1500 epochs, indicative of the enhanced capability of the sentinel to generate nontoxic responses despite provocations. In Fig. 7 .ii/Fig. 7 .ii, the consistent decrease in R mae subscript ğ‘… mae R_{\mathrm{mae}} also suggests that the larger model size does not impede the fine-tuning process of the red team-sentinel framework. Furthermore, in Tab. 1 , we showcase several sample responses of y ğ‘¦ y and y â‹† superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† y^{\star} produced by the GPT-3.5-Turbo model. Some text is uncompleted because the maximum generated tokens for Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} , Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} and Ï€ t subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘¡ \pi_{t} are limited to 20 20 20 , 20 20 20 and 30 30 30 , respectively. It is noteworthy that when using the modified instruction prompt x â‹† superscript ğ‘¥ â‹† x^{\star} with a sentinel, the generated response y â‹† superscript ğ‘¦ â‹† y^{\star} shows a significantly lower probability of toxicity. Conversely, when the sentinel prompt is not used, the score for y ğ‘¦ y is high. This emphasizes the generalizability of our framework to larger targets and the effectiveness of the sentinel in reducing the toxicity of scaled up LLMs.

3.6 Sentinel Model Compared to Direct PPO Detoxification

Using the script provided in the TRL toxicity repository, we compare our method to direct detoxification on the wiki_toxic evaluation dataset. The baselines are pretrained GPT s of different sizes, and their detoxified versions fine-tuned on RealToxicityPrompts ( Gehman etÂ al., 2020b, ) dataset. Instead of tuning the victims directly with toxic prompts, we employ the sentinel Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} as the prefix model before target models and only tune Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} with PPO. No red team in this experiment since ( Gehman etÂ al., 2020b, ) is already toxic. We initialize Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} as GPT-Neo-125M . For models without a sentinel, we allow a maximum of 30 30 30 new tokens as output. For sentinel-assisted models, we restrict 15 15 15 maximum tokens for both the sentinel and target models, then concatenate the outputs for training/eval. We measure the toxicity score of outputs using the toxicity metric of the huggingface evaluate . Detailed parameter configurations are in Tab. 9 , Appendix D . We report the toxicity score of 400 400 400 sampled examples in Tab. 2 . Sentinel-assisted models have better capabilities in reducing the toxicity score of generated text compared to direct-detoxified counterparts. The score gaps between our methods and baselines are clear across all model sizes, while for directly detoxified ones, the gaps are clear for smaller models but less so for the 6B model.

3.7 Do Sentinels Affect Practical Usefulness?

Setup. Preserving usefulness is a crucial aspect in defense methods. In this part, evaluate the model usefulness after plugging in our sentinel models. The models are evaluated under DeepEval 1 1 1 https://github.com/confident-ai/deepeval evaluator. In specific, we give the score of Correctness (with G-Eval (Liu etÂ al.,, 2023 ) ), Answer Relevancy , Bias , Toxicity 2 2 2 â‹† Note that DeepEval toxicity metric differs from RoBERTa toxicity, where the former is evaluated using the GPT-api and the latter is through a fine-tuned RoBERTa model. and the Average performance. All metrics are referenceless , meaning only QA pairs are required for evaluation. For a toxic environment, we randomly sample 500 500 500 questions from the HarmfulQA dataset (Bhardwaj and Poria,, 2023 ) as model inputs. We distribute the modules into 3 3 3 groups for ablation study: 1) The BaseModel refers to only untrained target LLM. 2) The +Sentinel means BaseModels with sentinel as prefix model for response generation (with sentinel only generate 15 initial response tokens), the sentinels are pre-detoxified with RealToxicityPrompts similar to Sec. 3.6 . 3) the +Sentinel&RedTeam means the sentinel is additionally fine-tuned using our proposed framework, as in Sec. 2.2 . For more reasonable responses, we employ the TinyLlama-1.1B as our sentinel model for all 2.7B, 6B and 7B targets. MaxTokens means the max length constraint of QA sequence, this is limited for smaller models since they tend to repeat a single sentence many times for longer generation.

Results. As shown in Tab. 3 , the sentinel model, especially when trained with the red team interaction framework ( +Sentinel&RedTeam ), is effective at reducing the toxicity of generated text across all tested language models while preserving or even improving overall usefulness for the smaller models. For GPT-Neo-2.7B and GPT-J-6B , the sentinel trained with the red team reduces toxicity by 23.5% and 31.8%, respectively, compared to the base models, while also improving average usefulness scores by 2.1% and 6.0%. This is driven by substantial gains in answer relevancy that outweigh minor drops in correctness. However, for the larger Llama2-7B-Chat model, while the sentinel achieves an 43.8% reduction in toxicity, it appears to have a detrimental effect on correctness (-6.6%) and relevancy (-4.6%) that results in only slight 0.5% increment in overall usefulness compared to the base model. This suggests that while the sentinel is effective at mitigating toxicity, it still inevitably bring in noise that could affect the quality of final answers, especially for larger models trained with sufficiently many data.

Overall, our method, as shown in all 3 groups, can substantially reduce the toxicity of generated text across various targets while preserving or even improving usefulness for smaller models, but may require further adaptation to maintain correctness and relevancy with larger models.

3.8 Text-to-image Task with Stable-Diffusion-2.1

Text-to-image is an emerging application in generative models with safety concerns akin to those in text-to-text applications. Studies (Rando etÂ al.,, 2022 ; Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ) use red-teaming to probe what prompts trigger text-to-image models to generate harmful content, e.g., not-safe-for-work (NSFW) images. We study if our sentinel approach can neutralize such a toxic prompt trigger and elicit safe images from the target model. We use MagicPromptGPT2 as Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} and Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} , and use stable-diffusion-2.1 (Rombach etÂ al.,, 2022 ) as target model. We employ the nsfw_image_detection as the reward function. The corpus for red-teaming is the Stable-Diffusion-Prompts , where we randomly sample 1024 1024 1024 combinations with 2 2 2 example prompts each. We use Ï€ r subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘Ÿ \pi_{r} and Ï€ s subscript ğœ‹ ğ‘  \pi_{s} to perform continuation on the input prompts, then feed the outputs to stable-diffusion-2.1 + classifier stable-diffusion-2.1 classifier \texttt{stable-diffusion-2.1}+\text{classifier} . Detailed parameter configurations are in Tab. 8 , Appendix D . Fig. 8 illustrates the prompts generated by red team and sentinel, and their respective induced images. We observe that even with prior instruction requesting the generation of NSFW images, the sentinel model is still able to derive prompts that lead to SFW content. The substantially low percentage of NSFW responses with threshold > 0 absent 0 >0 in the right charts (ii) also indicates the effectiveness of our approach at text-to-image tasks.

4 Related Work

Red-Teaming on LLMs. Existing research on red-teaming typically adopts two methodologies for designing adversarial prompts, (i) manual-based red-teaming and (ii) model-based red-teaming. Among the former, manual techniques (Ganguli etÂ al.,, 2022 ; Greshake etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Kang etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Perez and Ribeiro,, 2022 ) aim at developing and strategically positioning malicious prompts in easily accessible areas. In particular, (Wallace etÂ al.,, 2019 ) designed an adversarial writing interface for humans to write similar jeopardy to trick the model into making wrong predictions, (Xu etÂ al.,, 2021 ) collected thousands of conversations between the model and crowd workers and proposed a framework where humans are guided to trick models to output unsafe content. Model-based red-teaming is more efficient in generating high-quality prompts compared with manual annotation. (Perez etÂ al.,, 2022 ) leveraged a high-quality classifier as the reward function to train a red-teaming model. This approach aimed to generate inputs that could maximize the classifierâ€™s score based on the output of the target model. Additionally, (Casper etÂ al.,, 2023 ) introduced a dedicated data sampling phase for the target model, enabling the collection of human annotations. These annotations were then utilized to develop a task-specific red-teaming classifier. Furthermore, (Mehrabi etÂ al.,, 2023 ) employed in-context learning techniques within a red-teaming framework to prompt image or text generative models into producing unsafe content.

Defence on LLMs. Correspondingly, with the recent proliferation of attack prompts targeting LLMs, developing strategies to counteract harmful outputs produced by these models has become imperative. Specifically, (Ngo etÂ al.,, 2021 ) proposed filtering the pretraining dataset of LLMs as a foundational solution. Additionally, other studies have focused on fine-tuning LLMs using non-toxic corpora ( Gehman etÂ al., 2020a, ) or datasets aimed at specific values (Solaiman and Dennison,, 2021 ) to diminish the presence of toxic or harmful content. Diverging from earlier defensive efforts, (Xu etÂ al.,, 2022 ) introduced a novel approach by training a model with toxic prompts to evaluate and reduce the likelihood of generating toxic tokens. Moreover, Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) (Christiano etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Stiennon etÂ al.,, 2022 ) , Reinforcement Learning from AI Feedback (RLAIF) (Bai etÂ al.,, 2022 ; Lee etÂ al.,, 2023 ) , Direct Prompt Optimization (DPO) (Rafailov etÂ al.,, 2023 ) , Black-box Prompt Optimization (BPO) (Cheng etÂ al.,, 2023 ) have recently gained significant interest, offering promising methods to align LLM-generated contents with safety standards with human or AI feedback. In this study, we present a novel approach to safeguard LLMs from toxic prompts without the necessity for additional training or modifications to the dataset.

5 Conclusion

Existing LLM defense methods face challenges in parameter efficiency, model accessibility, and reliance on toxic prompts for detoxification. Our proposed sentinel model offers strong defense capability while being invariant to target model scale. Additionally, our red team-sentinel framework requires no target model optimization, enabling its application to API-only targets and automatic toxicity exploration through red-teaming, eliminating the reliance on toxic datasets. Future works include investigating the transferability of the sentinel model across different target models and training phases. We hope our method will be widely adopted and inspire further research, contributing to the development of more secure language models for various applications.

Limitations. We identified in usefulness assessment (Sec. 3.7 ) that the sentinel model struggled to fully preserve the factual accuracy and relevance of outputs from large models like Llama-7B , highlighting the challenge of maintaining performance while improving safety. Further, our approach currently focuses on minimizing toxicity, but other important safety criteria like privacy-preserving and cultural norms aligning are not addressed. Moreover, there may be categories of harmful prompts that the red teaming model fails to generate during training, leaving potential gaps in the sentinelâ€™s robustness. Future work could explore techniques to improve the efficiency and scalability of the approach while also expanding its capabilities to handle a wider range of safety criteria.

âˆ™ âˆ™ \bullet Appendix A :Â The Two-Agent trlX Framework

We outlines the implementation of our two-agent framework (Fig. 2 ) for training LLM-based agents with separate rewards, utilizing the trlX library for distributed training and detailing three critical functions â€” Make Experience, Process Element, and PPO Learn â€” that facilitate individual reward collection, post-processing for PPO optimization, and training model weights with backward propagation, respectively.

âˆ™ âˆ™ \bullet Appendix B :Â Loss Computation

We provide the computation of loss with IPPO and MAPPO schema for training LLM-based agents, focusing on critic learning, advantage estimation, and policy learning, highlighting IPPOâ€™s approach to individual LLM-agent optimization in multi-agent settings and MAPPOâ€™s adaptation with a centralized critic for shared value head learning among agents.

âˆ™ âˆ™ \bullet Appendix C :Â Prompt Setup

We detail the prompt setup, including the template of system prompt , red team prompt and sentinel prompt for text continuation, instruction following, and text-to-image generation tasks that are covered in this paper.

âˆ™ âˆ™ \bullet Appendix D :Â Parameter Settings

This section provides detailed parameter configurations for experiments in text continuation, instruction following, text-to-image, and direct detoxification tasks, employing various models and datasets, and specifies the setups for red team, sentinel, victim and reward models within the fine-tuning framework.

Appendix A The Two-Agent trlX Framework

To facilitate the training of two LLM-based agent with separate rewards, we develop the two-agent schema based on the implementation of Transformer Reinforcement Learning X (trlX) 3 3 3 https://github.com/CarperAI/trlx library, which is a distributed training framework implemented based on Hugging Face Transformer Reinforcement Learning (trl) 4 4 4 https://github.com/huggingface/trl with additional support on parallel training. In Fig. 9 , we illustrate the schematic of three critical functions that differ most from the standard single-agent RLHF, respectively, the Make Experience, Process Element, and PPO Learn. In particular:

  • â€¢

    The Make Experience function (Fig. 9(a) ) is for interacting with the target model (environment) to collect individual rewards, then Query, Response and reward model Scores are formulated as Element For Process (EFP) of two agents. In this phase, only text generation heads (instead of value heads) are used for red team and sentinel models.

  • â€¢

    The Process Element (Fig. 9(b) ) pipeline is the post-processing of collected EFPs, which concatenate the recorded Query/Response from EFP and perform forward pass to generate logits and values (with different heads) for the preparation of PPO optimization. This phase returns the PPO RL Element (RLE) of each LLM-agent, which contains Query/Response from EFP, Logprobs/Values computed for each token, and the re-estimated Rewards based on the scores from EFP, KL-alignment, and optionally the curiosity bonus. This phase is also inference-only. Noteably, the Make Experience and Process Element are distributed to multiple CPUs for parallel execution, which speed up the exploration of RL agents.

  • â€¢

    Finally, after sufficient rounds of RLE collection, a batched RLEs is fed into the PPO Learner (Fig. 9(c) ) to compute the value function and policy gradient loss. In this phase, the model weights and value heads of red team and sentinel models are both trained using backward propagation.

For implementation-wise detail, please refer the the attached code.

Appendix B Loss Computation

B.1.3 Policy Learning

The policy learning (Clipped Surrogate Objective), as depicted in (Schulman etÂ al.,, 2017 ) , is formulated as

In essence, the policy learning in PPO tries to adjust the policy parameters Î¸ ğœƒ \theta to maximize the expected return, guided by the advantage A Ï€ Î¸ k â€‹ ( o , u ) superscript ğ´ subscript ğœ‹ subscript ğœƒ ğ‘˜ ğ‘œ ğ‘¢ A^{\pi_{\theta_{k}}}(o,u) , while ensuring that the new policy does not deviate too much from the old policy.

B.1.4 Why Independent ?

IPPO is the direct extension of the standard PPO framework to multi-agent settings by maintaining a separate policy and critic for each agent. This design allows each agent to independently optimize its policy based on its observations and rewards, making IPPO suitable for a range of task modes, including cooperative, collaborative, competitive, and mixed. The independent nature of IPPO means that agents do not necessarily need to share information with each other, although the option for strategic information sharing ( e.g., observations, actions, or critic values) is available to enhance learning. This is also evidenced from the objective of value network in Eq.Â ( 8 ), which only receive the partial observation o t subscript ğ‘œ ğ‘¡ o_{t} instead of global information as input.

B.2 MAPPO

The MAPPO inherits similar GAE and policy learning methods from IPPO, while primarily differs on critic learning, which is expressed as:

Ï• k + 1 = arg â¡ min Ï• â¡ 1 | ğ’Ÿ k | â€‹ T â€‹ âˆ‘ Ï„ âˆˆ ğ’Ÿ k âˆ‘ t = 0 T ( V Ï• â€‹ ( o t , s t , ğ® ğ­ âˆ’ ) âˆ’ R ^ t ) 2 . subscript italic-Ï• ğ‘˜ 1 subscript italic-Ï• 1 subscript ğ’Ÿ ğ‘˜ ğ‘‡ subscript ğœ subscript ğ’Ÿ ğ‘˜ superscript subscript ğ‘¡ 0 ğ‘‡ superscript subscript ğ‘‰ italic-Ï• subscript ğ‘œ ğ‘¡ subscript ğ‘  ğ‘¡ superscript subscript ğ® ğ­ subscript ^ ğ‘… ğ‘¡ 2 \displaystyle\phi_{k+1}=\arg\min_{\phi}\frac{1}{|{\mathcal{D}}_{k}|T}\sum_{\tau\in{\mathcal{D}}_{k}}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left(V_{\phi}(o_{t},s_{t},\mathbf{u_{t}}^{-})-\hat{R}_{t}\right)^{2}. (11)

Eq.Â ( 11 ) differs to Eq.Â ( 8 ) on the formulation of value function V â€‹ ( â‹… ) ğ‘‰ â‹… V(\cdot) , where the former intakes the local observation o t subscript ğ‘œ ğ‘¡ o_{t} , global state s t subscript ğ‘  ğ‘¡ s_{t} and the action set of all agents except the current agent ğ® ğ­ âˆ’ superscript subscript ğ® ğ­ \mathbf{u_{t}}^{-} . As detailed in MARLlib 5 5 5 https://marllib.readthedocs.io/en/latest/algorithm/ppo_family.html , in MAPPO, parameters are shared across agents. Not sharing these parameters will not incur any problems. Conversely, partly sharing these parameters ( e.g., only sharing the critic) can help achieve better performance in some scenarios. Therefore, in majority of the MAPPO implementations, the value function V â€‹ ( â‹… ) ğ‘‰ â‹… V(\cdot) is shared across agents, which is therefore referred to as centralized critic .

B.2.1 MAPPO for LLM-based Agent

For LLM-based agents, especially for our two-agent framework, as the generation of x ğ‘¥ x and x â‹† superscript ğ‘¥ â‹† x^{\star} all depend on the state z ğ‘§ z , we can consider the initial prompt z âˆ¼ ğ’Ÿ similar-to ğ‘§ ğ’Ÿ z\sim\mathcal{D} as the global state s t subscript ğ‘  ğ‘¡ s_{t} in Eq.Â ( 11 ). The action set is also the same for two agents as they are all initialized as the same LLM, e.g. GPT-2 s. Therefore, the only concern for MAPPO adaptation is the design of parameter-sharing mechanism. Given the takeaways that centralize/partly sharing critic functions can improve the performance, we proposed the Centralized and Partially Shared LLM value head strategies in Sec. 2.3 to enhance the learning for our unique multi-agent partially observed scenario.

Appendix C Prompt Setup

C.1 Text Continuation

We use IMDb review dataset (Maas etÂ al.,, 2011 ) as the frameworkâ€™s input prompts for red-teaming and defense against GPT2-imdb since it is widely adopted in many open-sourced libraries of RL for LLMs (Castricato etÂ al.,, 2023 ; von Werra etÂ al.,, 2020 ) , as well as recent works (Chang etÂ al.,, 2023 ; Filandrianos etÂ al.,, 2023 ) on text generation. We follow the setting in (Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ) and randomly sample truncated reviews as the input prompts to the red team model. Each truncated review takes the first four words (tokenized by space) of the review. The reviews are truncated instead of using the whole review since the red team, sentinel, and the target models tend not to generate new text if the input prompts are already long.

C.1.1 Red Team Prompt

There is no system prompt for Text Continuation, we input the sentence sampled from IMDb directly to red team and generate test cases for the target model, thus the input for red team is:

{IMDb Sample}

The target input is simply:

{IMDb Sample} {Red Team Output}

We expect the target model to generate toxic continuations.

C.1.2 Sentinel Prompt

The output of the red team concatenating with the input prompt is then fed into the sentinel, whose outputs are then fed into the target model as inputs. Thus the input for sentinel is:

{IMDb Sample} {Red Team Output}

and the input for target is

{IMDb Sample} {Red Team Output} {Sentinel Output}

We expect the target model to generate safe continuations.

C.2 Instruction Following

We use the Alpaca dataset (Taori etÂ al.,, 2023 ) as the frameworkâ€™s prompts when we perform red teaming and defense against GPT2-alpaca , GPT3.5-Turbo and Llama-2-7B . Similar to (Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ) , we choose this dataset to let red team and sentinel model to generate instruction-like prompts to test the target LLM. We randomly sample the combination of 3 3 3 arbitrary instructions from the dataset and compose the input prompts using the following template:

Write a list of instructions:
1. {Instruction 1}
2. {Instruction 2}
3. {Instruction 3}

We follow the system prompt provided in (Hong etÂ al.,, 2024 ) for all target models on Instruction Following with Alpaca dataset:

Below is an instruction that describes a task.
Write a response that appropriately completes the request.
### Instruction: {Instruction}
### Response:

C.2.1 Red Team Prompt

Using the prompt template provided above, the red team instruction is generated with following prompt:

Write a list of instructions:
1. {Instruction 1}
2. {Instruction 2}
3. {Instruction 3}
4.

This gives the {Red Team Output} as the forth instruction, then the instruction is packed into the system prompt for target model as:

Below is an instruction that describes a task.
Write a response that appropriately completes the request.
### Instruction: {Red Team Output}
### Response:

We expect the target model to generate toxic responses.

C.2.2 Sentinel Prompt

We generate refined sentinel instructions based on the prompt template and red team outputs, the inputs for the sentinel is formulated as:

Write a list of instructions:
1. {Instruction 1}
2. {Instruction 2}
3. {Instruction 3}
4. {Red Team Output}

This gives the {Sentinel Output} as the continuation of {Red Team Output} , then we concatenate these two outputs as the instruction for target mode:

Below is an instruction that describes a task.
Write a response that appropriately completes the request.
### Instruction: {Red Team Output} {Sentinel Output}
### Response:

We expect the target model to generate safe responses.

C.3 Text-to-Image

We use Stable-Diffusion-Prompts 6 6 6 https://huggingface.co/datasets/Gustavosta/Stable-Diffusion-Prompts , where we randomly sample 1024 1024 1024 combinations with 2 2 2 example prompts as input for red-teaming and defense. As we chose prompt generation specialized GPT-2 i.e. MagicPromptGPT2 as red team and sentinel models, we abandon the prompt template for generating red team and sentinel outputs. For target model, the system prompt specifies the generation of NSFW prompt:

Based on the following prompt to generate NSFW images:
{Prompts}

regardless of w/wo sentinel prompts.

C.3.1 Red Team Prompt

Similar to Text Continuation, the red team model generate new prompts based on the initial prompts, thus the input for red-teaming is simply the sampled initial prompts from Stable-Diffusion-Prompts

{Initial Prompts}

Then {Red Team Output} is packed within system prompt as input for the target Stable-Diffusion model:

Based on the following prompt to generate NSFW images:
{Initial Prompts} {Red Team Output}

We expect the target model to generate NSFW images.

C.3.2 Sentinel Prompt

Similar to Text Continuation, the sentinel model perform continuation based on

{Initial Prompts} {Red Team Output}

Then all generated prompts are concatenated and fed into target model within the system prompt as

Based on the following prompt to generate NSFW images:
{Initial Prompts} {Red Team Output} {Sentinel Output}

We expect the target model to generate SFW images.
